Flordeliza is 26 and single. She lives in a village with her beloved parents. She engages herself in selling different kind of soft drinks in their village to help her parents in gaining income. She has operated this business for almost four years and usually earns a profits of PHP 6,000 a month, which she uses for their food, clothing and allowances of her younger sister.

She aims to improve her business to increase her income, but due to financial difficulty, she is asking for additional capital of PHP 14,000 to buy additional stocks of soft drinks like Gatorade, C2, Coke, Pop Cola, Sprite, Pepsi and Mountain Dew. 

She believes that this loan will help her to improve the business and hopes that she can make her business a viable source of income through patience and hard work.

loans.use: to buy additional stocks of soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Begaiym's Group

texts.en:
Begaiym is the treasurer of this group. She is 29 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband, she is bringing up a daughter and a son. Both children are preschool age. 

Begaiym works as a teacher at school. From time to time she sells apples and pears for making additional money to meet the family's needs. At the moment she is applying for the loan because she needs money to purchase fuel for preparing the land. In the near future, Begaiym plans to rent a piece of land for growing potatoes. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fuel.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a resident and a farmer in Kitale, Western Kenya. She is 41 and married, and she has four children between 19 and 4 years old. All are in  school. 

She has been in the farming business for 10 years, producing maize and eggs for the local market. She also trades in cereals in the local market for additional income.

Joyce has made a loan request of 80,000 KES with Juhudi Kilimo to purchase more poultry birds and build a bigger and better poultry unit in her farm. This is her third loan after two of 40,000 KES each. She says the loans have been beneficial and she hopes the third one will boost her business more by enabling her to buy more birds and build a bigger unit and help her meet her family's needs, especially educating her children.

She hopes to be the major supplier of eggs in the area.

She laments the high costs of feeds in farming.

loans.use: To purchase poultry birds and build a better poultry unit.

loans.name: Saierahon's Group

texts.en:
Saierahon is the treasurer of this group. She is 48 and married to a farmer. She has raised two sons, both of whom work in Russia. 

Saierahon works as a nurse in a sanatorium. She owns a piece of land, which is used for cultivating agricultural products. With the profits gained from selling the harvest, she buys livestock for breeding. 

At the moment she needs money to purchase feed for livestock, and for this purpose she is applying for the loan. 

In the future Saierahon plans to purchase a piece of land for growing cotton. She also wants to her sons to marry.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line: people (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase feed for livestock.

loans.name: Patricidra

texts.en:
Patricidra is married to Danilo Sr. Their marriage was blessed with four children: Danilo is 40 years old; the twins Rowena and Ronald are 31 years old and both are high school graduates; the youngest, Quincy, is 22 years old and a college student. They live in the Rizal province of Isabela, a place that has rough road conditions and that is far from the public market. 

Patricidra is in the direct selling business, selling Avon products. She needs more capital and she is now asking for a loan of PHP 25,000 that she will use for her direct selling business. She promised herself to exert more effort in selling to have additional income for the education of her youngest daughter.

loans.use: to purchase additional products for her business.

loans.name: Melabu

texts.en:
Melabu is a resident and a farmer in Kitale, aged 33. She has been in farming for seven years and currently employs one farmhand. Her farm produces milk and eggs, both sold to the local market. She is married and has six children between 12 and 1 year.

Melabu has requested a loan of 40,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase more poultry birds and boost her poultry farming business. She says her focus is to have more than 700 birds and expand beyond the local markets.

She laments of challenges posed by animal diseases, but she is glad Juhudi Kilimo loans have made life much better. This is her fourth loan request.

loans.use: To buy poultry birds.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine is 38 years old, single, and lives in Brgy. South Pob., Siquijor, Siquijor.
 
Catherine has a general store as a means of living and has had this business for 3 years. Each month she earns PHP 3,000.00 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan for PHP 7,000.00 to purchase more merchandise for her general store.

Catherine has been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for 6 months. She wants to expand her general store.

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise for her general store.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Rosalia is aged 59 and has been in farming for 9 years. She is married, with four adult children.  For the past 4 years, she has been producing milk, maize, and eggs for the local market.

Rosalia has requested for a loan of 60,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase more poultry birds for her business. This is her fourth loan request with Juhudi Kilimo and she says it will help improve her farming income and allow her to enjoy economies of scale. She says her focus is to repay the loan like the previous ones.

She says the greatest challenges are animal diseases and the high cost of feed.

loans.use: To purchase poultry birds

loans.name: Jenelyn

texts.en:
Jenelyn is 19 years old and lives in Lower Lamac, Oroquieta City. She is married and has one child.
 
Jenelyn has a charcoal business and earns approximately PHP 1,200 each month doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to purchase more charcoal for her business.
 
Jenelyn has been a member of PMPC for a year. She is a MIGS member of PMPC. In the future, she hopes to have a car.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal for her charcoal business.

loans.name: Milliana

texts.en:
Milliana is 37 years old. She is married and the mother of a 16 year old. For the past ten years, she has run a salon to earn a living.  Milliana has employed two people in her business.  Since she joined Faulu Kenya, she has been able to improve her business through previous loans and business management training.  This has helped Milliana to run her business in a better way.

Milliana is requesting a 50,000 KES loan to buy hair oil, hair treatment, and hair weaves. In the future, she dreams of opening additional business outlets.

loans.use: to buy hair oil, hair treatment, and hair weaves

loans.name: Merlita

texts.en:
Merlita is 56 years old and is married with six adult children. She is from the village of Rizal. To make a living, Merlita owns and operates a business raising pigs that she fattens and sells. Merlita has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells a grown pig. Merlita joined ASKI in 2007 to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. 

Merlita is requesting a new 23,000 PHP loan to purchase livestock feed and other supplies.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from her loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 29 years old and is married and blessed with two children. To earn a living, she sells cigarettes.  She started her business one year ago and employs one person to assist her.  Previously, she ran a cafeteria.  

Grace is requesting a 10,000 KES loan to add to her stock of cigarettes.  She dreams of expanding to a wholesale business.

loans.use: to purchase cigarettes

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en:
Jackson is a farmer in the Kitale area of Western Kenya. He is married with four children between five and 11 years old, all of whom are in school. For the past 21 years, Jackson has been a farmer. He currently produces maize, beans, and milk to sell at the local market and he employs two farmhands. 

Jackson is requesting his first loan with Juhudi Kilimo to venture into poultry farming. He says the purchase of poultry will enable him increase his income and make his business more secure. Jackson’s potential business threat is the outbreak of disease. However, he is convinced that the business will pay as there is a ready market for poultry in his area. Jackson is glad that Juhudi Kilimo has made farming loans available.

loans.use: to buy poultry

loans.name: Ishkhan

texts.en:
Ishkhan is 58 years old. He lives in Yerevan with his wife, who does not have a job. Ishkhan’s son lives and works in the Russian Federation.  For more than 30 years, Ishkhan has run a workshop where he repairs cars. He repurposed his home garage to do this. He has a lot of experience and therefore has never had a shortage of clients. He sometimes buys old and broken cars to repair and sell. Thanks to his business, Ishkhan is able to provide for his family.

Ishkhan is requesting a 3,000 USD loan to purchase a broken car to repair and resell.

loans.use: to buy a car to repair and resell

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is aged 53 and has been in mixed farming for the last 21 years. His farm produces pineapples and tea and runs on two farmhands. He is married with three adult children and a last born aged 12.

Patrick has made a second loan request for 90,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow and make a venture into dairy farming. He says the additional income will enable him educate his last born child. He says he is looking forward to making dairy farming business successful to boost his tea and pineapple farming.

He is glad Juhudi Kilimo helps smallholder farmers

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Chanvesna

texts.en:
Chanvesna (in the photo) is 30 years old and her husband, Sophal is 40 years old, have been married since 2001 and have two children-one son and one daughter. The family lives in a village along national road number two about twelve kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Chanvesna makes plastic souvenirs such as bracelets and sells them to an NGO, while her husband is a chef; he cooks for a restaurant in Phnom Penh. Chanvesna is requesting her first loan of $1,000 to build a fence around her house and buy a motorbike for her brother to drive to work.

loans.use: To build a fence around her house and buy a motorbike for her brother to drive to work.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en:
Luisa is 36 years old and had been widowed for almost 17 years. She has one child attending in his third year college education. To provide a good education for her child, she is selling processed meat products such as pork sausages, fish, pork and chicken meat. She operates the business in a stall located at the public market.

She needs to offer more food products to meet all her customers demand for affordable and high quality of products she sells because there are many competitors in the market. She wants to improve her sales. She is now asking for a loan of P50,000 to buy cured pork, sausages, hot-dogs, fish and chicken meat to sell in her food stall.

In the future, she wants to have a good financial management and continue acquiring good income from her business. She wants to save enough money for future expenses.

loans.use: to buy cured pork, sausages, hot-dogs, fish and chicken meat to sell in her food stall

loans.name: Vener

texts.en:
Vener is a 47 year old father who raised his family in a village. He aimed to educate his two children and give them a better future. Despite the hardships of life, he is striving hard to earn income and support the education of his children. He is one of the jeepney drivers in their village for almost 10 years and usually earns a profits of P7,000 a month that he used to acquire their necessities and allowances of their children.

He wants to ask for an additional capital of P13,000 to buy gasoline, wheels and spare parts for his jeepney. He believes that through this loan, he can continuously use his jeepney and provides a better service to his passengers. He is hoping that he can able to increase his income and give his family a better future.

loans.use: to buy gasoline, wheels and spare parts for his jeepney

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is a vegetable vendor in her village. She buys vegetables in bulk and then sells them at retail price. She is planning to expand her business in order to increase her income. Therefore, she would like to request a loan of PHP 15,000.00. Teresita believes she must be diligent enough to work hard to achieve her goals and send her children to school so they can have a better future. She hopes that her business will continue to grow and that she will have a permanent business stall in the market. 

Teresita is now 42 years old. Her husband Bernando is working as a farmer. They live in the village of Rizal, with their two children: Mary Ann is 17 years old and in her first year of college, and Mary Jane is 15 years old and in her fourth year of high school. Teresita is thankful her family is still happy even in times of crisis. She hopes and prays to God that her family will remain healthy and away from any harm.

loans.use: to buy cabbage, tomato, carrots, garlic and onions

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie is 31 years old and is married with two children. She lives in Tuyabang Alto,Oroquieta City. She has a general store and earns approximately 5,000 PHP each month from her business. Julie has been a member of PMPC for five years.

Julie is requesting a 50,000 PHP loan to purchase stock for her general store.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her general store

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan is 37 years old and has one school-age child. He is a responsible parent and strives to improve his family’s living standard and provide a better life. For the past five years, Jonathan has worked as a van driver in his village and usually earns a monthly profit of 7,000 PHP. His profit is used for the family’s basic necessities and for allowances for his child. 

Jonathan is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan to buy spare parts and gasoline to maintain his van and continue to use it for his business. He believes that through patience and hard work he will be able to increase his income and support his family.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and gasoline to maintain his van

loans.name: Elvie

texts.en:
Elvie is 32, married, and blessed with three children. She lives with her family in Don Domingo near the public market. With a good site to establish a business, Elvie took advantage of the opportunity and opened a store where she sells kitchenware such as glass, pitchers, and basins. She usually earns a monthly profit of 3,000 PHP that she uses to pay for school fees, electric bills, and family meals. 

Elvie is requesting a 15,000 PHP loan to buy hangers, basins, and glassware to sell in her store. These additional items will help improve her sales. In the future, Elvie would like to keep improving her sales and increasing her earnings to pay for the college education of her children.

loans.use: to buy hangers, basins, and glasswares to sell in her store

loans.name: Wesley

texts.en:
Wesley was born 31 years ago in the Litein area of South Rift Kenya. He is married with three children between the ages of one and four. For the past 10 years, Wesley has been a farmer and he produces milk and potatoes that he sells at local markets. He employs one farmhand. Wesley also sells tea that he buys from other farms to gain additional income. 

Wesley is requesting a 49,920 KES loan from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. He says an additional dairy cow will boost his milk production and his income and enable him educate his children. He adds that better income will improve his family's general living standards. Wesley is happy with Juhudi Kilimo loans and training services but he advocates for the organization to help farmers access better markets for their products to avoid the losses occasioned by fluctuations in market prices.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en:
Visitacion is married to Roberto and the couple was gifted with five children: Joji, 30 years old; Pampi, 27 years old; Kenneth Ian, 25 years old; Roberto Jr., 22 years old, and Nińo, 20 years old. Her children are all high school graduates. Visitacion is in the business of buying and selling fruits and vegetables in her village. She wakes up early every morning to buy vegetables in the market and then sell them in her village at retail price. 

Visitacion is requesting a 14,000 PHP loan to buy more goods such as cabbage, tomatoes, and beans, to increase her income. She hopes that her request will be granted and her loan will help her business grow.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Diosdado

texts.en:
Through patience and hard work, Diosdado is able to support his family needs and finance the education of their children. He is now 59 years old and has four adult children. He used to operate his motorcycle transport to generate additional income. He aims to earn and save more income to improve their house and save for their future.

He is asking for a loan of P10,000 to buy gasoline, spare parts and pay the registration fee of his motorcycle. He believes that through this loan, he will continuously use his tricycle to earn income.

loans.use: to buy gasoline, spare parts and pay the registration fee of his motorcycle

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is aged 37 and is engaged in both farming and transport business using his motorcycle. He is married with 3 children aged between 4 and 1 year and has also been in active farming for 10 years in his home area of Litein,South Rift Kenya. His farm currently produces milk for the local market.

Paul has requested for a loan of 62,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says the boost in his farming income will help him educate  his children. He anticipates the farming business will continue to grow to better heights. 

He is glad with Juhudi Kilimo loan services but advocates for training especially on artificial insemination for dairy cows to be able to get the specific breeds they want.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Precila

texts.en:
Precila is a hardworking mother. She helps her husband do some activities in the farm. The couple had been raising crops for almost three years. They usually plants and harvest rice and future sell it to local traders in the village where they live. Her husband plows the field and sometimes pays for laborers who helped them in sowing seeds in the rice field. 

She is requesting a loan of P10,000 to buy seeds and pay for laborers who helped in transplanting rice seedlings.

In the future, she wants to achieve abundant harvest every harvest season to continuously finance the schooling of her children.

loans.use: to buy seeds and pay for laborers who helped in transplanting rice seedlings

loans.name: Nurjamal's Group

texts.en:
Nurjamal is the leader of this group. She is 31 and married to a farmer. Together with her husband she brings up two sons and two daughters. The older son studies at school and the other children are preschool age (under seven). In order to earn money to meet the family needs the couple breeds livestock and cultivates agricultural products. At the moment Nurjamal applies for the loan because she needs money to increase the number of livestock. With money received from the loan she will purchase sheep for breeding. In the future with the profits gained form reselling livestock she plans to repair the house.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase feeds for livestock business

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina is 45 years old and lives in small village of Bontod, Province of Siquijor.  She is married with four children.
To earn a living, Gina has a business selling of Assorted Fruits, Spices and Vegetables. She earns about PHP 5,000.00 every month doing this type of work. She has a requested a loan amounting to fifteen thousand pesos for additional investment in the said business.

Gina has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for one year.  Gina would like to let her children finish studying now in college and land a good job in the future through the financial help of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative.

loans.use: To purchase Fresh Fruits, Spices & Vegetables to sell in the market everyday

loans.name: Baktygul's Group

texts.en:
Baktygul, 23, is a leader of this group. For the past year the entrepreneur has been involved in retail of sea food and meat products including cod and pluck. Baktygul obtains the wholesale in a big market of the capital Bishkek and resells it back in her hometown of Balykchi. The demand for her products rises quite rapidly, so sometimes she holds trips several times a week.  Despite having three young aged children, she manages to fulfill all her duties. Big help is shown from the side of her husband who helps her in transportation of goods, which takes up to five hours. The business generates around 8 000 soms monthly , thanks to which the couple made savings for a purchase of an automobile. The loan is planned to be an additional sum of funds needed for the purchase of an automobile. She hopes it will decrease her transportation expenses.

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a car

loans.name: Hulkarkhon's Group

texts.en:
Hulkarkhon, 42, is a leader of this group. She’s been gathering rich harvest of potatoes every fall season for the past six years. Throughout these years agricultural products have been unstable due to many reasons , including potatoes, which are highly consumed in local cuisine. These ups and downs hit thousands of farmers including Hulkarkhon who faced financial losses. Nevertheless, recent two years brought fixed high price for potatoes, which pushed the growth of supply. It is the high time to gather crops, however some final touches need to be made. This necessity motivated Hulkarkhon to apply for a loan. She feels lucky to have this land, which was received during privatization in 1990s, because it feeds her big family of 6 people. A monthly income of 3 000 soms has allowed her to make major repairing in the house. Hulakarkhon requests the loan in order to purchase mineral fertilizers. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Samiarah

texts.en:
Samiarah is a smart and honest woman. She is married to a businessman and she is a loving mother of four children.  She works diligently to provide a good quality of life for her family. 

In order to earn money and support her family, Samiarah became involved in retail sales at the public market of Santiago City. She started her business in 1981 with the sales of women's and men's outerwear and other kind of dry goods. She wants to obtain a loan amounting to P20,000 for the purchase of stock blouse, pants, shorts and other kinds of dry good products for her clothing sales business. She would be glad if her request loan will be granted to maintain the business she manages. Maintaining her business would really help her most especially in increasing the income she manages and providing the allowances of her children.

loans.use: to purchase stock blouse, pants, shorts and other kinds of dry good products for her clothing sales business

location.town: Mabini Street, Victory Norte, Santiago City

loans.name: Begaim's Group

texts.en:
Begaim, 46, is a leader of this group. Living in a remote, isolated village of Mangyt in Southern Kyrgyzstan she has been working in a local medical laboratory for twelve years. She is known among the village dwellers not only as a caring medic and a mother of five children, but also as a promising farmer with extensive experience in entrepreneurship. Begaim and her husband, who is a tractor driver during the agricultural season and a construction worker the rest of the year, have two younger children, who are still financially dependent on them. The house the family is living in is fairly old and any furnishings made were helpless. Now is the time for construction of a new small-sized house, however 8 000 soms salary earned by Begaim cannot cover both family expenses and the purchase of inputs for construction. “A loan from Kiva was the best option for me and my family,” she says. Right after receiving funds from Kiva lenders, Begaim looks forward to purchase the construction materials, like cement for laying the foundation of the house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase building materials

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 38 years old and single. He has been active in farming in his hometown of Litein for the last eight years. His farm produces milk and tea which go to the local market. He also runs a motorcycle transport business (on which he is pictured above).

Charles has requested a loan of 60,320 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He anticipates more growth in his farming business with the availability of the loan to purchase a dairy cow to add in his farm. He says the additional income will improve his standards of living as well as spread his business risks by getting income both from dairy and transport.

He sees challenges in sourcing funds, but is glad Juhudi Kilimo is mitigating the limitation.

loans.use: purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Barry Van

texts.en:
Barry Van is 23 years old and lives in Rizal, Zamboanga Del Norte. He is married with two children. 

Barry Van has a lumber business and earns approximately 10,500 PHP each month doing this type of work. He has a requested a loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase trees for lumber purposes. Barry Van has been a member of PMPC for 4 months.

loans.use: to purchase trees for lumber purposes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy canned goods, noodles, beverages, soft drinks, and seasonings to sell

loans.name: Fracis

texts.en:
Fracis is 35 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Soroti region of Uganda. He is married and has two children. For the past 4 years, Fracis has been working hard to manage his small shop, which makes and sells clothes. 

To help expand his business, Fracis has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more traditional Ugandan dresses, called gomeses, for resale, and will help Fracis to generate greater profits and to lay a foundation for a house on the plot his family has already purchased. Fracis hopes that in the future he will be able to finish building his own home so that he no longer has to pay rental costs. 

Fracis is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Fracis who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy traditional Ugandan dresses for resale

loans.name: Glocille

texts.en: Glocille is 43 years old and lives in Poblacion, Rizal Zamboanga Del Norte. She is married with three children. Glocille has a shop that sells cosmetics and other beauty products. She has had this business for four years. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase more skin moisturizers, perfumes, lipsticks, fingernail polishes, eye and face makeup preparations, shampoos, permanent waves, hair colors, toothpastes, and deodorants.

loans.use: to purchase more cosmetic and beauty products for her shop.

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose is 62 years old and lives in Caluya, Sapang Dalaga. He is married with four children. 
Jose works in the fish industry and sells fish for a living. He has been doing this for 20 years. He has requested a loan of 20,000 to purchase 10 boxes of fish to sell. 
Jose has been a member of PMPC for 5 years.

loans.use: To purchase 10 boxes of fish to sell

loans.name: Maria Lisa

texts.en:
Maria Lisa is 30 years old and lives in Pangi, Siquijor, Siquijor.  
She is married with two children.
Maria Lisa sells of Food Vending to earn a living and has had this business for seven years.  Each month, she earns of PHp 2,000.00 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan amounting to fifteen thousand pesos only to purchase  Assorted Ingredients for Food Vending.  
Maria Lisa has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for one year.  In the future, Maria Lisa hopes to grow up her business and allocate savings deposit for her children's brighter future.

loans.use: To purchase  Assorted Ingredients for Food Vending

loans.name: Baktygul's Group

texts.en:
Baktygul is the leader of this group. She is 42 and she brings up two daughters. Both daughters go to kindergarten, they are preschool age (under seven). Baktygul works as a secretary in a "Rural justice". In order to earn additional money to meet the family needs she breeds livestock. Ten years ago she got a livestock inheritance from her parents and since that time she has been breeding livestock. From time to time if she needs money she can sell some animals. At the moment Baktygul wants to increase the number of livestock. For this purpose she applies for the loan, with money received from the loan she plans to purchase three sheep for breeding.

 --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Cherilyn

texts.en:
Cherilyn is 39 years old and lives in Sepac, Sapang Dalaga. She is married with five children. 
To earn a living, Cherilyn has a business selling snacks and other delicacies. She earns about PHP 2500 each month doing this type of work. Cherilyn has  requested a loan of 20,000 to purchase fertilizer for her corn.
Cherilyn has been a member of PMPC for 4 years.

loans.use: To purchase 10 sacks of fertilizer for her corn

loans.name: Salima's Group

texts.en:
Salima, 44, is a leader of this group. She resides in a remote village of Ogontala with her husband and four children. Currently Salima gathers and resells nuts and along with it breeds cattle. In fifteen years of running this business the family has built a shop and is still running this shop. Salima can hardly believe that initial capital was 5 000 soms, and now it benefits several times more. The purpose of Salima’s loan is to buy four heads of cattle. In the future she hopes to build a house for her children. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is 32 years old and lives in the town of Mityana in the Mubende region of Uganda. She is married and has three children, two of whom currently attend school. For the past four years, Sarah has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells stationery supplies. 

To help expand her business, Sarah has requested a loan of 2,000,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase papers and pens to sell in her shop, and will help Sarah to generate greater profits and pay her family's bills. Sarah hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another stationery shop on the other side of town. 

Sarah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Sarah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more paper and pens for resale

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 44 years old and has been in farming in his home area of Kitale for 15 years. He produces maize, beans, and eggs with the help of one farmhand, and sells these products to the local market. He is married and has three children between the ages of 10 and 17. He also operates a retail shop in the local market.

James has made a loan request of 50,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase more poultry for his poultry-farming business. He says this will improve his income, given his experience in the business. Later he will use the income to venture in dairy farming and diversify his trade for more secure income. He adds that reliable income will help him educate his children.

However, he laments of common animal diseases.

loans.use: To purchase poultry birds

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy soft drinks, beverages, noodles, snack foods, canned goods, seasonings, and soaps to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a business-minded woman and hardworking mother to her only child. Her husband sells cell phone accessories. Agnes has been operating her phone accessories business for four years. She said that through her small business, she is able to sustain the needs of her family with the help of her husband. 

Agnes would like to buy housing of cell phones and chargers for her retail shop, but she does not have enough funds due to household expenses and allowances of her child. She is strongly determined to maintain and improve her business, so she is asking for additional capital of 20,000 PHP. With this loan amount, she could satisfy her customers' demand. Agnes hopes to continue expanding her business to provide her family with a good standard of living and a good quality of education.

loans.use: to purchase housing of cell phones and chargers

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 36 years old and lives in the town of Kumi in the Soroti region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, two of whom are currently in school. For the past four years, John has been working hard to manage his retail shop, which sells food and home supplies. 

To help expand his business, John has requested a loan of 1,500,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more rice, sugar, and other supplies for the shop. It will help John generate greater profits and finish paying for the construction of a rental room that is attached to his house. John hopes that in the future he will be able to move into wholesale selling. 

John is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like John who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more rice, sugar and other supplies

loans.name: Antonieto

texts.en:
Antonieto is 54 years old and lives in Conat Aloran, Misamis Occidental.  He is married with children.  Antonieto has a fish vending (selling) business and earns approximately PHP 3,000 each month doing this type of work. He has requested a loan of PHP 14,900 to purchase more fish for fish vending. 
Antonieto has been a member of PMPC for a year. In the future, Antonieto hopes to have a fishing boat. Antonieto is a MIGS member of PMPC. Antonieto is a hard working father and has a happy family.

loans.use: to purchase more fish for his fish vending business.

loans.name: Olmaskhan's Group

texts.en:
Olmaskhan, 42, is the leader of this group.  For twenty years she has been running a dairy business, distributing milk and homemade milk products to regular buyers.  It took much effort and trying several different types of businesses before she focused on milk production. 

For a long period of time, Olmaskhan was a farmer, gathering crops each fall.  She later switched to retail, selling food products in a local market.  After that, she bought cattle and made the first attempts at milk retail. The business was started with the small amount of 5,000 soms.  She now makes twice that amount each month.  Olmaskhan has two young kids and, not long ago, gave birth to a third child. The toddler needs care and good conditions. Olmaskhan hopes to receive her portion of the loan, which she will spend on the purchase of a baby carriage. 

 --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (being environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan.  Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a baby carriage.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en: Gladys is 58 years old and has five children. For the last 10 years, she has earned a living by running a grocery store where sells many different kinds of fruit. She supplements her income by raising cows and selling their milk. Gladys has been successful because she is determined and works hard. Her membership in Faulu Kenya has also helped because it gives her access to business loans which she uses to improve her business. She is applying for a loan for 50,000 Kenya shillings to buy oranges to sell in her shop and a new cow to raise.

loans.use: To buy oranges and a cow.

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is 30 years old and lives in the Mubende region of Uganda. She is married and has two children who are both currently in school. For the past three years, she has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which is located just off a busy highway and contains mostly food items for sale.

To help expand her business, Irene has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. She will use the loan to buy more foodstuffs to sell in her shop. This will help her increase her profits and pay for her children's school fees. In the future, she hopes to have one of the biggest and most prosperous businesses in town. 

Irene is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program mainly serves small entrepreneurs who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more food items to sell in her store.

loans.name: Nazira's Group

texts.en:
Nazira, 34, is a member of this group. She resides in the small town of Kerben in northern Kyrgyzstan. Nazira is married to a farmer and they have three young children. Unfortunately, Nazira doesn’t get to see them during the day due to her occupation of cattle reselling. Most of her time is spent on taking care of the cattle and taking them to a stockyard for reselling at a good deal. She got involved in this activity two years ago following the advice of her sister and invested start-up capital of 28,000 soms. She has spent the generated profit well, by buying electrical appliances and improvements for the house. Currently she receives 10,000 soms a month and hopes to save enough for the purchase of a car in the future. The purpose of the loan is to invest back in the business for the turnover of capital. 


 --- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
Jonathan is 30 years old and lives in the town of Lugazi in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past three years, Jonathan has been working hard to manage his small store, which sells pesticide and farm supplies to local farmers. 

To help expand his business, Jonathan has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase new types of pesticides and increase his inventory as necessary, and will help Jonathan to generate greater profits and provide for his family. Jonathan hopes that in the future he will be able to own a business with 20mil UGX of capital. 

Jonathan is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Jonathan who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase new types of pesticides

loans.name: Abdulmoin

texts.en: Abdulmoin is the very kind and hardworking 53-year-old father of five children, two of whom are currently in college. For the last 30 years, he has earned a living by selling clothing. During a typical month, he generates about PHP 6,000 in income. He is applying for a loan for PHP 20,000 to buy more clothing to sell to his customers and to improve and redecorate his shop. His goal is to earn enough money to put all of his children though college and also begin setting money aside for when he and his wife grow older.

loans.use: to restock and improve a clothing store.

location.town: Aguinaldo Street, Victory Norte Santiago City

loans.name: Marcela

texts.en:
Marcela is 50 years old and lives in Pasay, Philippines. She is a widow with one child who is now in high school. She earns a living by running a variety store where she sells groceries, toiletries and beverages to neighbors and passersby. She generates about PHP 3,000 in sales during a typical day. Marcela is applying for a loan for PHP 10,000 to buy more items to sell to her customers. Her goal is to earn enough money to provide her child with a first-class education. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who meet weekly to study religion, build social capital and repay microloans.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell in her variety store.

loans.name: Artak

texts.en:
Artak is 45 years old and lives in Ijevan city with his wife and daughter. Artak’s wife stays at home to care for their child. In the past, he was employed at a woodworking complex in Armenia, then worked in Russia for three years. In 1997, he returned to Armenia and set up his own business of selling fruit and vegetables. From time to time, he rents a truck to travel into the countryside to buy produce to sell, then returns to Ijevan city to sell these items from his stall. 

Artak's business has allowed him to support his family, but he is applying for a loan for 700,000 AMD to buy his own truck so that he can travel more often and buy more produce. His goal is to decrease his expenses and increase his income. This is his fourth loan from Nor Horizon; he repaid the first three fully and on time.

loans.use: to buy a truck to use when buying and transporting produce.

loans.name: Twelwaneko Nabingoola Group

texts.en: Margret needs another loan to buy a microscope for her clinic. She used the previous loan to buy drugs for her clinic and has been able to save money from the profits earned. Her major challenge is lack of enough equipment to use and her dream is to have a fully equipped clinic. She is a member of the above mentioned group in which each member guarantees the other and their mission is to struggle and get out of poverty.

loans.use: to buy a microscope for her clinic.

loans.name: Jeenaiym's Group

texts.en:
Jeenaiym is the leader of this group. She is 50 and married to a constructor. She takes care of a grandson, who is just 5 years old. In order to earn money to meet the daily needs, the family breeds livestock. They started this business nine years ago with an initial investment of 10,000 soms and now reselling some livestock after fattening they earn about 2,500 soms per month. With money received from the loan Jeenaiym wants to increase the number of livestock. In the future she hopes to leave a good inheritance to her children. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy shoes for resale.

loans.name: Chynarbubu's Group

texts.en:
Chynarbubu, 45, is the leader of this group. Living in a village of Karajygach, where all dwellers either breed cattle or cultivate land, Chynarbubu didn’t have another choice of occupation. Having moved here, Chynarbubu with her husband and two sons became full-fledged members of the community. She bought the very first head of cattle for 8,000 soms. Growing cattle and reselling it brought the good result of purchasing furniture for the house. Despite the fact that the house still needs more electrical appliances and improvements, Chynarbubu believes she will accomplish this goal one day. With the purpose of purchasing a refrigerator, she now addresses Kiva lenders. She hopes to open a farm in the far future. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase a fridge.

loans.name: Anagina

texts.en:
This is Anagina, 30, resident of Pasay, Philippines. Single, she manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Anagina operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from this, she also sells direct-selling products to her customers. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Anagina hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams of opening a restaurant someday. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Munduzkhan's Group

texts.en:
On one of the typical days of spring, the family of Munduzkhan opened a tiny shop for food retail. It was the idea of Munduzkhan’s eldest daughter to invest the long-kept family savings in a start-up of such a small but profitable business. As for any business, the location was very important. After spending a certain amount of time in search of the place, Munduzkhan finally found a nice spot in a local train station, because it is often full of passengers ready to get some food. 

After seventeen years of running the business, the family purchased an automobile and arranged wedding ceremonies for the daughters. Munduzkhan wishes to expand her business into a big grocery store in the future. Now she asks Kiva lenders for funds which will be invested in broadening the goods circulation. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase macaroni, sugar, oil and beverages.

loans.name: Serapio

texts.en: Serapio wants another loan to buy cement for resale in his retail shop. He used the previous loan to start up a section of hardware items and he is amazed by the growth of the business after diversifying his shop. His challenge is limited funds to purchase the right quantity, and his dream is a big hardware shop.

loans.use: to buy cement for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To open another mobile-phone / money-transfer business.

loans.name: Wilma

texts.en:
This is Wilma, 43, resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is married to Allan, a vendor. They have three children. She, together with her husband and children, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.
  
Wilma operates a buy and sell business. What she basically does is buy general merchandise from wholesalers, then sell it for a little profit. Her products are footwear, sandals and other products of the like. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options she offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities and varieties of sandals and slippers to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Wilma dreams to have her own house someday and also to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for products needed in her business.

loans.name: Khoem

texts.en:
Khoem is a 53-year-old married man with four children. He is from Kompong Speu province of Cambodia and is a farmer. Two of his children have started their own families, so he lives with his wife and his two single children. Khoem is very hard-working; besides farming, he earns money by playing traditional Khmer instruments for wedding parties and other ceremonies as needed. 

With the coming rainy season, Khoem is concerned about his farming business because he has no strong animals for plowing the fields. He is requesting a loan from HKL and Kiva to buy some cows for use on his farmlands. He hopes that he’ll be able to expand his business and gain more profit in the future.

loans.use: to buy some cows for use on his farmlands.

loans.name: Kyarumba United Group

texts.en: Betty is a 30-year-old married woman with two children. She owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been in the salon business for six years. She started by working for someone else and now she has her own salon. Her vision is a model salon, children’s education, and a sound and healthy family. Betty needs a loan to buy supplies for the salon such as weaves and cosmetics.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her salon including weaves and cosmetics.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius is 33 years old, married, and blessed with one child.  To earn a living, he offers transport services.  He uses his cart to transport water, eggs and vegetables to specific customers.  He has engaged in the business for seven years.  

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been trained on savings and business management.  This has helped him to improve his business.  He has requested 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy another cart.

loans.use: To buy another cart.

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
This is Lucena, 52, resident of Batasan, Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Leonilo, a driver, and is the mother of her only child.  She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Lucena operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from those small ones pictured to the much larger doormats. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. She also earns additional income from direct-selling products. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php200 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials for her business. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business.  

Lucena hopes to grow her business in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her child a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy clothes to resell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a forty-year-old single mother of four children, renting a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been selling bananas and beans for four years, and the business is profitable, as she has been able to pay school fees for her children. Her hardship is high transport charges, and her vision is a food store plus an educated family. Mary needs the loan to buy bananas and palm oil for resale.

loans.use: to buy bananas and palm oil for resale.

loans.name: Neverless

texts.en: Neverless is a forty-year-old married woman with five children, and she owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been selling bananas and beans for five years and this has helped her in supporting the family. Her hardships are high transport costs and thieves, and her vision is business expansion, a well-furnished house plus educating her children. Neverless needs the loan to rent land for farming and to buy bananas.

loans.use: to rent land for farming and to buy bananas.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a computer for his business.

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is 32 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has four children, with two of them currently in school. For the past year, Margret has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Margret has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sugar and soap for resale and will help Margret to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Margret hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business. 

Margret is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Margret who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more sugar and soap for resale.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en: Monica is a 32-year-old single mother of five children who rents a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been selling bananas and beans for four years and with the money she earned, has been able to educate her children. Her hardship is high commodity prices. Her dream is to own a food store, a good house, and finish educating her children. Monica requests a loan to buy more beans for selling.

loans.use: to buy beans for selling.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary, a 41-year-old married woman with six children, owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. She has been dealing in second-hand clothes for 12 years, having  gotten her initial capital from farming. Her hardships are inflation and high taxes, and her goals are to open a boutique and educate her children. Mary is now requesting a loan to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell.

loans.name: Oyuntuya

texts.en:
Oyuntuya is 37 years old, has two sons, and lives with her family in a small house located in an outer ger district, lacking basic infrastructure, of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. She is a chieftain of the commission where her family lives. Her work responsibilities are to take care of elderly people and to help the homeless to receive government assistance. She really enjoys her job.  Oyuntuya’s spouse is a first sergeant in a local military force, while their sons attend secondary school and kindergarten. 

The family lives in a very small house, which needs some renovation work, such as covering it with a roof, daubing the walls, and refreshing the paint on the fence's door. In the winter, her house is very cold, her children often get sick, and it is very hard to live in when the outside temperature is far below zero degrees; in summer time, it rains. Therefore, she is planning to do housing renovations this autumn, before winter. Oyuntuya is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 Mongolian Tugriks to purchase essential construction materials, such as cement, roofing, paint and wood.  She said, “If Kiva lenders will give me an opportunity to make my family safe and cozy, I’ll really appreciate it."

loans.use: to buy essential construction materials which needs in house - renovation work.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy medecine for her pharmacy.

loans.name: Leng

texts.en:
Mrs. Leng is a 35-year-old married woman who lives in Kompong Speu province. She lives with her husband and two children who attend a local state school. Since 1998, she has earned a living by cultivating a rice crop. She learned this skill from her parents very well. 

She normally makes around $1.50USD per day to help with the family's expenses. With this little profit, Mrs. Leng cannot cover all of the family’s needs. They also depend on her husband's income from collecting, hauling, and selling firewood.

Mrs. Leng requests a loan to purchase mineral fertilizers and other necessary agricultural materials for growing rice during the rainy season. She said that this loan will help her produce more rice than in previous years. For the future, Mrs. Leng wishes to see her children graduate from university and  get good-paying jobs.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers and other necessary agricultural materials to grow rice for selling.

loans.name: Njuguna

texts.en:
Njuguna, a 46-year-old man, is married and has two children. To earn a living, he sells kerosene. He has been in the business for ten years. He has employed two people in his business. He also owns rental houses which earn him extra income. 

Njuguna hopes to expand his business and employ more people. He has requested 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy kerosene.

loans.use: To buy kerosene

loans.name: Janepher

texts.en:
Janepher is 26 years old, married and blessed with a six-year-old child. She sells cosmetics at wholesale so as to earn a living. She has been in the business for only one year. She has managed to employ one person. She also does farming to boost her income. She was previously employed before she went into business for herself. 

Janepher hopes to own a car in the future. She has requested 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy shampoo.

loans.use: To buy shampoo

loans.name: Vakhtang

texts.en:
Vakhtang is 31 years old. He lives in Vardablur village, Lori marz. Vakhtang is married and he has two small children: a son and a daughter. 

Vakhtang is a worker at gold-mining organization. At the same time he is engaged in animal breeding and land cultivation. On his farm Vakhtang breeds a cow, a calf, and two pigs. Also he has a garden where he grows various fruits and also pumpkins. Vakhtang uses pumpkins as a fodder for his farm animals. 

He intends to develop a cattle breeding operation which will allow him to produce dairy products not only for his family's use but also for sale. Therefore Vakhtang is asking for an 800,000 Armenian Dram (AMD) loan to buy four or five calves for his farm.

loans.use: to buy 4 or 5 calves for his farm

loans.name: Mirzobek

texts.ru: Мирзобек женат и у них один ребенок. Он умный и ответственный человек. Мирзобек занимается услугой таксиста. Год назад он приехал из России, где он был на заработки. На заработанные деньги он купил автомобиля марки «Мерседес» и начал заниматься услугами таксиста. Каждый день рано утро он уедет на транспортировки пассажиров и вечером поздно вернется домой. Он хорошо ухаживает на свою машину и поэтому у него много постоянных клиентов. Мирзобек хотел бы получить займ для ремонта своего автомобиля. Он заранее благодарить всех вас за вашу доброту и помощь.
texts.en: Mirzobek is married and has one child.  He is a smart and responsible person.  Mirzobek is involved in providing a taxi service.  He came from Russia one year ago, where he used to work.  He used the earned money to buy a Mercedes car and started to provide a taxi service.  He leaves for work early every morning to transport passengers and returns home late in the evening.  He takes good care of his car and, hence, has many loyal customers.  Mirzobek wants to obtain a loan to make repairs to his car.  He thanks all of you in advance for your kindness and help.

loans.use: to make repairs to his car

loans.name: Mandiaye

texts.fr: C'est un commerçant, il habite dans une région du Sénégal. Il s'active dans le domaine du commerce depuis plus de 15 ans. Avec ce prêt il va faire une embouche en achetant des moutons et des chèvres destinés à la vente. Mais aussi, ce crédit est utilisé pour acheter des poissons qu'il va revendre sur le marché.Le but de ce prêt est destiné aussi a l'achat de nourriture pour les bêtes. Il compte acheté un champ dans sa localité pour avoir une espace afin de mieux entretenir ses troupeaux.
texts.en: This borrower is a trader and lives in a region of Senegal.  He has been in business for more than 15 years.  He will use this loan to buy livestock to fatten.  He will buy sheep and goats which he will later sell.  He will also use this loan to buy fish, which he will re-sell on the market, and feed for his animals.  He plans to buy a field in his town so that he will have a space where he can better look after his animals.

loans.use: to buy sheep and fish

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cell phone equipment

loans.name: Mukhfuza

texts.ru: Мухфуза замужем и любящая мать одного ребенка. Её муж рабочий. Она занимается купля продажей тканей на местном рынке. Она продает широкий ассортимент тканей и у неё много постоянных клиентов. Мухфуза хочет расширить свой бизнес и пополнить своего оборотного капитала. Она запрашивает займ в размере 5000 Сомони для покупки нового ассортимента тканей. Она заранее благодарить кредиторов за их понимание и доброты.
texts.en: Mukhfuza is married and is a loving mother of one child.  Her husband is a worker.  She is involved in buying and selling fabrics at the local market.  She sells a wide variety of fabrics and has many loyal customers.  Mukhfuza wants to expand her business and add to her revolving capital.  She is requesting a loan in the sum of 5000 Somoni to buy a new assortment of fabrics.  She thanks the creditors in advance for their understanding and kindness.

loans.use: to buy a new assortment of fabrics

loans.name: Wilfred

texts.en:
Wilfred is a father of two children aged 5 and 10, who live with him in their home in Kitale, Western Kenya, where he practices mixed farming. He has been in farming for five years and his farm produces milk and eggs which go to the local market. He is 35.

Wilfred has requested a loan of 76,200 Kenyan Shillings (KES) from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase more poultry for 45,000 KES and a dairy cow for 31,200 KES. He says the additional income will improve his family's living standards and make his businesses grow as he plans to reinvest in it. He hopes to be a major supplier of milk in the area. 

He points at food shortages as the main challenge he faces.

loans.use: To purchase poultry and a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a larger quantity of pepper for sale

loans.name: John

texts.en: John used his previous loan to add stock of electronic goods.  He witnessed a lot of growth in his business. He was able to pay school fees for his children comfortably.  He hopes to have a well-established business and employ people. John has requested a loan of 50,000 Kenya shillings to use as capital to start a business of selling plastic containers.

loans.use: To open a business of selling plastic containers

loans.name: Adama

texts.fr: Elle s'active dans le domaine de la vente de produits cosmétiques et de nettoyages depuis plus de 20 ans. Habitant dans une ville proche de la capitale du Sénégal, cette femme sollicite ce prêt pour acheter des marchandises afin de renforcer son stock de marchandises et d'acheter des produits (parfums, laits, savons, et des produits de lessives) qu'elle va placé sur le marché vue qu'elle n'a pas de cantine au marché , elle envisage avec les bénéfices qu'elle va avoir d'en louer une pour être plus près des clients
texts.en: She has been active in the domain of selling cosmetic and cleaning products for over twenty years. Living in a city near the capital of Senegal, this woman is requesting a loan to buy some goods in order to bolster her stock of merchandise and to buy products (perfumes, lotions, soaps, and laundry products) that she is going to put up for sale given that she lacks a stall at the market. She envisions using the profits she will make to lease a stall to be closer to customers.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy dozens of slippers to add to her business

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi has requested a loan of 100,000 Kenya shillings to add stock of carrots and potatoes and to buy a dairy cow.  She was able to improve her business with her previous loan.  Hence, she raised her standard of living with the increased profits from her business.
Naomi desires to run a wholesale business in the future.

loans.use: To buy carrots, potatoes and a dairy cow

loans.name: Stanley

texts.en:
Stanley is aged 44 and has been in farming for the last 15 years in his home area of Nkubu in Central Kenya. He is married, with 3 children aged 12, 10 and 3. His farm produces tobacco, maize, beans, peas and bananas for the local market.  He employs two farmhands on a casual basis.

He has requested a loan of 45,000 from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a water pump.  He says the tank will eradicate insufficiency of water which has been the greatest limitation in farming.  He believes the improved income will uplift his family's living standards and education by paying their school fees.

Stanley mentions poor transportation system and insufficient water as the main challenges.  He adds that Juhudi Kilimo really helps the smallholder farmer.

loans.use: To purchase a water pump

loans.name: Mirkiyaz

texts.ru:
